I have two odd fears. I wish I could stop them, or at least explain them, but I’ve never been able to break them.
1- Being touched. I can not be touched by anyone without panicking. If anyone, even a close friend or parent, tries to touch me, or even just brush against me, I’ll panic. There is only one person I know who I am mostly okay with, and sometimes enjoy, being touched by. I can not give hugs for too long without having to pull away. I’ll get very uncomfortable with even handshakes.
2- The elderly. Possibly because I have never been close to any of them on a social level, or maybe because of how handsy they can get, I will get paranoid every time I see an older person. One time a group I was with for the summer had to go to a nursing home, and I had to go with them to make bracelets for them. Even walking to the building from the transport vans was stressful. Getting inside and seeing everyone hooked up to these machines was so much worse. People left and right were either in beds, in wheelchairs, using walkers, or something else, and they were all elderly. I start to panic. Then they put me with a blind woman to make bracelets with, even though they knew I can’t move my hands correctly with most tasks. I’m over there trying to help her and be as nice as I can, but I’m struggling severely. So she was over there, touching my hands with hers, I didn’t know what to do, and it scares me just thinking about it.

Now everyone thinks I’m an awful person for not wanting to help out with the elderly, give hugs or handshakes, or not wanting to meet their parents or grandparents.

Linked here from Matt's video. There's a more roundabout way anxiety(being scared) kills: Depression. 

Take my instance. I am now disabled due to generalized anxiety disorder. I'm also middle aged, and missed my chance to get married and have kids. I lost my career and will never work again. I have no purpose, no hope and basically have to waste the days away while fighting off general panic over nothing. Because of the impact anxiety has had on me, I reached a tipping point- nothing really matters anymore since I can't get back my youth, so the things that I once would have done to combat the impact the anxiety has on me- eating well, exercising, etc.- I have given up on. I mean, if you're not going to have kids or a wife or a career, is there really a reason to go out of your way to avoid a heart attack at 50? Not really. It's like slow suicide, basically- and it all stems from being scared. 

The worst part is, anxiety is not helped by the amount of knowledge you have toward the disease, or your general IQ, or other coping techniques you learn. Everything you learn/know goes out the window as soon as the next panic wave sets in and makes you once again feel like you're having a heart attack or stroke. It's the worst thing in the world. =/

"The genes preparing us to instinctively avoid [the most consistent threats throughout our evolution] became more common while genes that did not faded away".

Guys, we really need to stop talking like this, as it is seriously misrepresenting the field of developmental neuroscience. The relationship between genes and behaviours is NOT simply a matter of gene X leading to behaviour Y. For a good overview, try:

Fisher (2006) Tangled webs: Tracing the connections between genes and cognition. Cognition 101, 270-297.
Gottlieb (2007) Probabilistic epigenesis. Developmental Science, 10(1), 1-11
Meaney (2013) Epigenetics and the biological definition of gene x environment interactions. Child Development, 81(1), 41-79.
